article.title: Kronos & Krios: Evidence for accretion of a massive, rocky planetary system in a comoving pair of solar-type stars

choices: Differences in the estimated positions and velocities of stars Krios and Kronos.
The distribution of stars in the Milky Way galaxy.
The chemical composition of stars Krios and Kronos.
The light curves of stars Krios and Kronos.

multiple_choice_question.text: What key finding is shown in Figure 2?
choices: Krios and Kronos have identical chemical compositions.
Krios has a higher abundance of heavy elements compared to Kronos.
Kronos exhibits a higher abundance of refractory elements compared to Krios.
Both stars are depleted in lithium.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information can be derived from the Galactic orbits depicted in Figure 7?
choices: The likelihood of Krios and the Sun being born in the same star cluster.
The chemical composition of Krios and Kronos.
The presence of planets around Krios.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from the comparison shown in Figure 9?
choices: Chemical inhomogeneity in the birth cloud is the likely cause of the abundance difference.
Exchange scattering events best explain the observed data.
The abundance differences are within the range expected from measurement errors.
The observed abundance patterns strongly suggest accretion of rocky planetary material by Kronos.
